Some may argue that simplifying complex ideas is necessary to make them accessible to a wider audience, and that this is not necessarily patronizing but rather a way of democratizing knowledge. Others may say that oversimplifying ideas may lead to misunderstandings or misinterpretations, and that it may be more respectful to present the ideas in their full complexity, even if it means some readers will struggle to understand them.

Ultimately, it may depend on the intentions of the author and the needs of the intended audience. In Wesley's case, he was deeply committed to spreading his message of Christian perfection to as many people as possible, and saw the need to present it in accessible language to reach the broadest possible audience.
